title: Preparing for Honest Self-Assessment
description: Before you complete the Skills Self-Assessment, let's make sure you're ready to be honest with yourself about where you are.

settings.skipNudgeMessage: This helps you get more value from the self-assessment. Skip anyway?

questions.prompt: Which of the following is the BEST description of 'soft skills' in a professional context?
options: Skills that are easy to learn
Non-technical skills like communication, collaboration, and self-management that determine how effectively you work with others
Skills that aren't important for technical jobs
Personality traits you're born with and can't change
questions.hint: Think about what makes someone effective on a team, beyond their technical abilities.
questions.explanation: Soft skills are learnable capabilities that affect how you work, communicate, and collaborate. They're called 'soft' not because they're easy, but because they're harder to measure than technical skills.

questions.prompt: Why does this course start with a skills self-assessment?
options: So the professor can judge your weaknesses
Because you can't improve something you haven't honestly identified
To compare yourself to other students
To prove you already have soft skills
questions.hint: What's the first step in any improvement process?
questions.explanation: Self-directed learning begins with honest self-awareness. You can't work on a skill gap if you haven't acknowledged it exists.

questions.prompt: Match each barrier to honest self-assessment with how to overcome it:

pairs.right: Remember: assessment is private, not shared with classmates
Focus on specific behaviors, not vague impressions

pairs.left: Overconfidence in areas you haven't tested
pairs.right: Ask: 'When was the last time I actually demonstrated this?'
Knowing ABOUT something isn't the same as being able to DO it

questions.hint: Each barrier has a specific mindset shift that helps overcome it.

questions.prompt: Understanding the difference between knowledge and skill:
questions.template: Reading about public speaking is {{knowledge}}. Successfully presenting to a difficult audience is {{skill}}. This course focuses on developing {{focus}}.

options: knowledge
skill
talent
practice
knowledge
skill
talent
theory
knowledge
skills through practice
natural talent
theoretical understanding

questions.hint: Think about the difference between understanding something intellectually and being able to execute it under pressure.

questions.prompt: When you identify a skill gap in your self-assessment, what's the most productive way to think about it?
options: I'm just not good at this — it's not my strength
This is an area where I can grow if I put in deliberate effort
I should focus on my strengths and avoid situations requiring this skill
Everyone has gaps, so it doesn't really matter
questions.hint: What mindset leads to actual improvement?
questions.explanation: A growth mindset treats skill gaps as opportunities, not permanent limitations. The whole point of this course is that soft skills CAN be developed through deliberate practice.

questions.prompt: How does honest self-assessment connect to job interviews?
options: It doesn't — interviews are about presenting your best self
Interviewers respect candidates who can articulate their growth areas and what they're doing about them
You should hide your weaknesses in interviews
Only mention weaknesses that are really strengths in disguise
questions.hint: What impresses experienced interviewers more — false confidence or genuine self-awareness?
questions.explanation: Strong candidates show self-awareness. 'I've identified that I struggle with X, so I've been working on Y' is much more impressive than pretending to have no weaknesses.

questions.prompt: Think about the last group project, job, or team experience you had. Identify ONE specific moment where a soft skill gap (yours or someone else's) caused friction or problems. What was the skill? What happened?
questions.placeholder: Be specific. Example: 'In my capstone project, I avoided giving honest feedback to a teammate whose code was buggy because I didn't want conflict. The skill gap was 'giving constructive criticism.' This led to us having to rewrite their section the night before the deadline.'

questions.prompt: Before starting the formal self-assessment, list 2-3 soft skill areas you SUSPECT might be growth opportunities for you. It's okay if you're not sure — this is a starting hypothesis.
questions.placeholder: Consider areas like: communication (written/verbal), receiving feedback, giving feedback, time management, handling ambiguity, conflict resolution, self-advocacy, active listening, asking for help, saying no, leading without authority, following through on commitments...
